Award.AwardTitle: The International Symposium on Computer Architecture (ISCA) 2019 Travel Grant

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Symposium on Computer Architecture (ISCA) is a premier forum for research on computer architecture, the hardware/software interface, and systems architecture. This award provides travel support for up to 20 students attending this flagship conference in June 2019 at Phoenix, Arizona, USA. ISCA embraces systems research that directly targets these new problems in new ways. Historically, the conference has attracted top research papers from both academia and industry, and many innovations published in the proceedings have been influential in the history of the processor industry. The acceptance rates for submitted papers is typically between 15-20%.

This award will have two primary direct benefits. First, The ISCA conference is strengthened as a result of better student attendance that this travel support enables, since they are the next-generation of the research workforce in this domain. Second, those students receiving travel support personally benefit from the opportunity to interact with peers and experts, as well as to establish connections that will help their professional careers. An undergraduate workshop at the event is one part of the computer architecture communities' efforts towards increasing diversity, and the travel funding seeks to also support students from underrepresented groups within the undergraduate attendees at the event.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Symposium on Computer Architecture (ISCA) is a premier forum for research on computer architecture, the hardware/software interface, and systems architecture. This project aimed to support this flagship conference by obtaining travel support for students in order for them to mitigate the costs of attending and participating in the ISCA conference in June 2019 in Phoenix, Arizona, USA. Priority was given to US citizens and permanent residents, followed by students from underrepresented groups, followed by students that will be presenting their research at ISCA or its joint workshops. Women and other under-represented groups were strongly encouraged to apply. We used a majority of the travel grant funds to support undergraduate student attendance at ISCA as a way to increase diversity and improve the "leaky pipeline" of underrepresented groups in computer science.

In total, we funded 20 graduate students of which 80% were underrepresented minorities and 50% were first time conference attendees. By targeting these two groups of students we are contributing to broadening participation in computing. Additionally, this funding was used in conjunction with donations from industry to fund the Undergrad Workshop is to encourage undergraduate students (including URMs) who are interested in computer architecture. We awarded travel grants to 37 students to attend the conference including hotel, plane flights, and registration to decrease the barrier to attend the workshop. After attending the workshop, 17 students (74% of respondents) said they were more likely to start a PhD program in computer architecture, while another 17% said they were more likely to start a PhD program in computer science, but not necessarily in architecture.
